text: The Emancipation Proclamation was issued in 1863, not at the start of the Civil War.
false: The Emancipation Proclamation was issued in 1861 at the start of the Civil War.
note: Issued Jan 1, 1863; the war began in April 1861

text: The United States purchased Alaska from Russia, not from Canada.
false: The United States purchased Alaska from Canada.
note: Purchased from Russia in 1867 for $7.2 million

text: Cleopatra lived closer in time to the Moon landing than to the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza.
false: Cleopatra lived closer in time to the construction of the Great Pyramid than to the Moon landing.
note: Great Pyramid ~2560 BC; Cleopatra ~30 BC; Moon landing 1969 AD

text: The Declaration of Independence was signed primarily on August 2, 1776, not July 4.
false: The Declaration of Independence was signed on July 4, 1776.
note: July 4 was when it was adopted by Congress; most delegates signed Aug 2

text: The Titanic sank on its maiden voyage in 1912.
false: The Titanic sank on its maiden voyage in 1906.
note: Sank April 15, 1912

text: Magellan did not personally complete the first circumnavigation of the Earth; he died in the Philippines.
false: Ferdinand Magellan completed the first circumnavigation of the Earth.
note: Magellan was killed in 1521 in the Philippines; Juan Sebastian Elcano completed the voyage

text: The ancient Library of Alexandria was not destroyed in a single catastrophic fire.
false: The Library of Alexandria was destroyed in a single great fire set by Julius Caesar.
note: It declined over several centuries through multiple incidents and neglect

text: The Salem witch trials resulted in the execution of 20 people, primarily by hanging.
false: Hundreds of people were burned at the stake during the Salem witch trials.
note: 20 executed (19 hanged, 1 pressed); no one was burned

text: Christopher Columbus was not the first European to reach the Americas; Norse explorers arrived centuries earlier.
false: Christopher Columbus was the first European to reach the Americas.
note: Leif Erikson reached North America around 1000 AD

text: The Roman Empire fell in 476 AD in the West, but the Eastern Roman Empire continued until 1453.
false: The Roman Empire fell completely in 476 AD.
note: The Byzantine Empire (Eastern Rome) lasted nearly another millennium

text: Marie Antoinette almost certainly never said "Let them eat cake."
false: Marie Antoinette famously said "Let them eat cake" to starving French peasants.
note: The phrase predates her and was attributed to her by Rousseau writing about an unnamed princess

text: The Great Fire of London in 1666 killed relatively few people, likely fewer than ten recorded deaths.
false: The Great Fire of London killed thousands of people.
note: Only 6 verified deaths, though the true toll may be somewhat higher

text: Paul Revere did not ride alone shouting "The British are coming"; multiple riders spread the alarm.
false: Paul Revere rode alone through the night shouting "The British are coming."
note: William Dawes and Samuel Prescott also rode; colonists still considered themselves British

text: The Bastille held only seven prisoners when it was stormed on July 14, 1789.
false: The Bastille was packed with hundreds of political prisoners when it was stormed in 1789.
note: Seven prisoners: four forgers, two mentally ill men, and one aristocrat

text: The Spanish Inquisition lasted for over 350 years, from 1478 to 1834.
false: The Spanish Inquisition was a brief period of persecution lasting about 20 years.
note: Formally established 1478, not officially abolished until 1834

text: Gladiatorial combat in ancient Rome did not always end in death; many bouts were non-lethal.
false: Gladiatorial combat in ancient Rome always ended with the death of the loser.
note: Gladiators were expensive to train; most bouts were fought to submission

text: The Iron Maiden torture device is likely a 19th-century fabrication, not a medieval instrument.
false: The Iron Maiden was a widely used medieval torture device.
note: No authenticated medieval examples exist; likely invented by showmen in the 1800s

text: Mussolini did not make the trains run on time; Italian rail punctuality did not significantly improve under fascism.
false: Mussolini made the trains run on time in Italy.
note: Largely fascist propaganda; most improvements predated his regime

text: The Aztec Empire was conquered by a combination of Spanish forces, indigenous allies, and disease, not by Cortes alone.
false: Hernan Cortes conquered the Aztec Empire single-handedly with a small band of conquistadors.
note: Tens of thousands of indigenous allies and smallpox were decisive factors

text: The Hundred Years' War between England and France actually lasted 116 years, from 1337 to 1453.
false: The Hundred Years' War lasted exactly 100 years.
note: A series of conflicts from 1337 to 1453

text: Nero almost certainly did not fiddle while Rome burned; the fiddle had not been invented yet.
false: Emperor Nero played the fiddle while watching Rome burn in 64 AD.
note: The fiddle was not invented until the Middle Ages; accounts say he may have played a lyre

text: The Pyramids of Giza were built by paid laborers, not by slaves.
false: The Pyramids of Giza were built by slaves.
note: Archaeological evidence shows organized labor forces with medical care and proper burials

text: Benjamin Franklin proposed the turkey as a national symbol in a private letter, not in an official vote.
false: Benjamin Franklin officially proposed the turkey as the national bird of the United States.
note: He mentioned it in a letter to his daughter, not in any official capacity

text: The Dark Ages is a misleading term; significant cultural and scientific progress occurred in medieval Europe.
false: No significant cultural or scientific progress occurred during the Dark Ages in Europe.
note: Modern historians reject the term; universities, cathedrals, and innovations flourished

text: Napoleon sold the Louisiana Territory to the United States in 1803.
false: Thomas Jefferson conquered the Louisiana Territory from France.
note: Purchased for approximately $15 million

text: Electrons do not orbit the nucleus like planets; they exist in probability clouds called orbitals.
false: Electrons orbit the nucleus of an atom in fixed circular paths like planets around the Sun.
note: The Bohr model is a simplification; quantum mechanics describes probability distributions

text: A teaspoon of a neutron star would weigh approximately 6 billion tons on Earth.
false: A teaspoon of a neutron star would weigh about the same as a teaspoon of lead.
note: Neutron star density is approximately 10^17 kg/m^3

text: Sound cannot travel through a vacuum because it requires a medium to propagate.
false: Sound can travel through the vacuum of outer space.
note: Sound is a mechanical wave that requires particles to transmit vibrations

text: Helium is the second most abundant element in the universe, after hydrogen.
false: Oxygen is the second most abundant element in the universe.
note: Hydrogen ~75%, helium ~24% of baryonic matter by mass

text: Absolute zero is approximately minus 273.15 degrees Celsius, not minus 459.67.
false: Absolute zero is minus 459.67 degrees Celsius.
note: -459.67 is Fahrenheit; -273.15 is Celsius

text: Bananas are slightly radioactive due to their potassium-40 content.
false: Bananas contain no radioactive material whatsoever.
note: Potassium-40 is a naturally occurring radioactive isotope

text: Rust is iron oxide, not a biological growth or living organism.
false: Rust is a type of fungus that grows on metal surfaces.
note: Rust is Fe2O3, formed by the oxidation of iron in the presence of water and oxygen

text: The Coriolis effect does not determine which direction water drains in toilets and sinks.
false: The Coriolis effect causes toilets to flush in opposite directions in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.
note: At the scale of a toilet, basin shape and water motion dominate; Coriolis is negligible

text: Oxygen is colorless as a gas but pale blue as a liquid.
false: Liquid oxygen is colorless, just like oxygen gas.
note: Liquid oxygen has a distinct pale blue color due to absorption of red light

text: A person could survive briefly in the vacuum of space without a spacesuit; they would not instantly explode.
false: A person exposed to the vacuum of space would instantly explode.
note: Skin is strong enough to contain the body; unconsciousness occurs in ~15 seconds

text: The Mpemba effect describes how hot water can sometimes freeze faster than cold water under certain conditions.
false: Cold water always freezes faster than hot water under identical conditions.
note: Named after Erasto Mpemba; mechanisms debated but the phenomenon is well-documented

text: Steel is an alloy of iron and carbon, not a pure element.
false: Steel is a pure metallic element found in the periodic table.
note: Steel is primarily iron with 0.2-2.1% carbon by weight

text: Noble gases can form chemical compounds under extreme conditions.
false: Noble gases are completely inert and can never form chemical compounds.
note: Xenon hexafluoroplatinate was synthesized in 1962; many xenon and krypton compounds are known

text: The pH of pure water is 7.0 only at 25 degrees Celsius; it varies with temperature.
false: The pH of pure water is always exactly 7.0 regardless of temperature.
note: At 100C, pure water has a pH of about 6.14, though it is still neutral

text: The half-life of carbon-14 is approximately 5,730 years, not millions of years.
false: The half-life of carbon-14 is approximately 50 million years.
note: This is why radiocarbon dating is only useful for objects up to ~50,000 years old

text: Most of the mass of a proton comes from the binding energy of quarks, not from the quarks themselves.
false: The mass of a proton comes almost entirely from the mass of its three quarks.
note: Quark rest masses account for only about 1% of the proton mass; the rest is QCD binding energy

text: Antibubbles are the opposite of soap bubbles: a thin shell of air surrounding liquid.
false: Antibubbles are a theoretical concept that cannot actually exist in nature.
note: Antibubbles are real and can be created by dropping soapy water onto a soapy surface

text: Metals can be transparent to visible light if made thin enough, typically below 100 nanometers.
false: Metals are always completely opaque to visible light regardless of their thickness.
note: Gold leaf transmits green-blue light; this is well-established physics

text: A flame in zero gravity is spherical, not teardrop-shaped.
false: A flame in zero gravity is teardrop-shaped, just like on Earth.
note: Without convection from gravity, the flame forms a sphere around the fuel source

text: Dry ice is frozen carbon dioxide, not frozen water.
false: Dry ice is simply very cold frozen water that appears white.
note: Dry ice is solid CO2 at -78.5C; it sublimates directly to gas

text: Saturn would theoretically float in water because its average density is lower than water.
false: Saturn is far too dense to float in water.
note: Saturn's density is ~0.687 g/cm3, less than water at 1.0 g/cm3

text: Antimatter has been successfully created and contained in laboratories.
false: Antimatter is purely theoretical and has never been produced in a laboratory.
note: CERN regularly produces antihydrogen; the first anti-atom was trapped in 2010

text: Venus is hotter than Mercury despite being farther from the Sun, due to its thick greenhouse atmosphere.
false: Mercury is the hottest planet in the solar system because it is closest to the Sun.
note: Venus surface temperature averages ~465C vs Mercury's ~167C average

text: Ostriches do not bury their heads in sand when frightened.
false: Ostriches bury their heads in the sand when they are scared.
note: They may press their heads flat to the ground from a distance this may look like burial

text: Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
false: Octopuses have one heart and red blood like most animals.
note: Two branchial hearts pump blood through the gills; one systemic heart pumps it through the body

text: Istanbul straddles two continents, Europe and Asia.
false: Istanbul is located entirely within Europe.
note: Divided by the Bosphorus strait; historically Constantinople

text: The capital of Brazil is Brasilia, not Rio de Janeiro.
false: The capital of Brazil is Rio de Janeiro.
note: Brasilia was purpose-built and became the capital in 1960

text: The capital of Turkey is Ankara, not Istanbul.
false: The capital of Turkey is Istanbul.
note: Ankara became the capital in 1923 when the Republic was founded

text: Africa is a continent, not a country.
false: Africa is the largest country in the world.
note: Africa contains 54 recognized sovereign countries

text: Russia spans eleven time zones, more than any other country.
false: Russia spans four time zones.
note: From Kaliningrad (UTC+2) to Kamchatka (UTC+12)

text: The Amazon River is the largest river by volume of water flow, but the Nile is generally considered the longest.
false: The Amazon River is both the longest and the largest river in the world.
note: Nile is traditionally listed as longest (~6,650 km); Amazon has the greatest discharge

text: The Dead Sea is a landlocked salt lake, not an actual sea connected to the ocean.
false: The Dead Sea is connected to the Mediterranean Sea.
note: A hypersaline lake on the border of Jordan, Israel, and the West Bank

text: The Sahara Desert is not the largest desert on Earth; Antarctica is larger.
false: The Sahara is the largest desert on Earth.
note: Antarctica is a polar desert at 14.2M km2 vs Sahara at 9.2M km2

text: The capital of Myanmar is Naypyidaw, not Yangon.
false: The capital of Myanmar is Yangon.
note: Capital moved from Yangon to Naypyidaw in 2006

text: Greenland is an autonomous territory of Denmark, not an independent country.
false: Greenland is an independent country.
note: Self-governing but part of the Kingdom of Denmark

text: Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador, not Mount Everest, is the farthest point from Earth's center.
false: The summit of Mount Everest is the farthest point from the center of the Earth.
note: Due to Earth's equatorial bulge, Chimborazo's summit is ~2,168m farther from Earth's center

text: The capital of Canada is Ottawa, not Toronto or Montreal.
false: The capital of Canada is Toronto.
note: Ottawa has been the capital since 1857

text: The Canary Islands are named after dogs, not canary birds.
false: The Canary Islands are named after the canary bird.
note: From Latin Canariae Insulae meaning Island of Dogs; the birds were named after the islands

text: Lake Baikal in Russia is the deepest lake in the world and contains about 20% of the world's fresh surface water.
false: The Great Lakes in North America contain more fresh water than any other lake system.
note: Baikal reaches 1,642 meters depth and holds ~23,615 km3 of water

text: The capital of Switzerland is Bern, not Zurich or Geneva.
false: The capital of Switzerland is Zurich.
note: Bern is the de facto capital (federal city); Switzerland technically has no official capital

text: Scotland is part of the United Kingdom, not an independent country.
false: Scotland is an independent country separate from the United Kingdom.
note: Scotland is one of four countries within the UK

text: The Strait of Gibraltar separates Europe from Africa, with a minimum width of about 14 kilometers.
false: The Strait of Gibraltar separates Europe from Asia.
note: Separates Spain from Morocco, connecting the Atlantic to the Mediterranean

text: Hawaii is farther south than any point in the continental United States.
false: Key West, Florida is farther south than any point in Hawaii.
note: Hawaii's Big Island extends to about 19N latitude; Key West is about 24.5N

text: Timbuktu is a real city in Mali, not a mythical or fictional place.
false: Timbuktu is a fictional place used as a metaphor for somewhere far away.
note: A historic city in Mali that was a major center of learning in the 15th-16th centuries

text: The capital of Nigeria is Abuja, not Lagos.
false: The capital of Nigeria is Lagos.
note: Capital moved from Lagos to Abuja in 1991

text: The word "salary" derives from the Latin word "salarium," related to salt, not from "solar" meaning sun.
false: The word salary comes from the Latin word for sun because workers were paid at sunrise.
note: Possibly related to Roman soldiers' salt allowances, though the exact connection is debated

text: A split infinitive (e.g., "to boldly go") is grammatically acceptable in English.
false: Split infinitives are grammatically incorrect in English.
note: The prohibition was an artificial rule borrowed from Latin grammar; no basis in English

text: Ending a sentence with a preposition is grammatically acceptable in English.
false: It is always grammatically incorrect to end a sentence with a preposition in English.
note: Another artificial rule imposed by 17th-century grammarians modeling English on Latin

text: The word "decimate" originally meant to kill one in ten, not to completely destroy.
false: The word decimate has always meant to completely destroy or annihilate.
note: From Roman military punishment where every tenth soldier was killed

text: Eskimo languages do not have hundreds of words for snow; this claim is a linguistic myth.
false: Eskimo languages have over 200 unique words for snow.
note: Debunked by linguist Geoffrey Pullum; the number is comparable to English snow-related terms

text: The word "irregardless" is widely considered nonstandard, with "regardless" being the correct form.
false: Irregardless is a fully standard English word meaning the same as regardless.
note: Listed in dictionaries but marked as nonstandard; the ir- prefix is redundant

text: The ampersand (&) was once the 27th letter of the English alphabet.
false: The English alphabet has always had exactly 26 letters.
note: Children recited 'and per se and' after Z, which slurred into 'ampersand'

text: The word "mortgage" comes from Old French meaning "death pledge," not "monthly payment."
false: The word mortgage comes from a French word meaning monthly payment.
note: From mort (death) + gage (pledge): the deal dies when paid off or when payment fails

text: The word "factoid" was coined by Norman Mailer to mean a false fact, not a trivial true fact.
false: The word factoid has always meant a small interesting piece of true information.
note: Mailer coined it in 1973 to mean something that looks like a fact but isn't; usage has shifted

text: Chinese is a family of related languages, not a single unified language.
false: Chinese is a single language with minor regional accent differences.
note: Mandarin, Cantonese, Wu, Min, etc. are mutually unintelligible spoken languages

text: The word "inflammable" means the same as "flammable," not its opposite.
false: Inflammable means not flammable or fire-resistant.
note: The in- prefix here is from Latin meaning 'into' not the negating prefix

text: There is no rule in English that forbids starting a sentence with "and" or "but."
false: Starting a sentence with 'and' or 'but' is always grammatically incorrect in English.
note: A persistent classroom myth; major style guides permit it

text: Sign languages are complete natural languages with their own grammar, not simplified versions of spoken languages.
false: Sign languages are just visual representations of the local spoken language with no unique grammar.
note: ASL has different grammar from English; BSL is unintelligible to ASL users

text: The word "gymnasium" comes from the Greek word "gymnos" meaning naked, because Greeks exercised nude.
false: The word gymnasium comes from the Greek word for education.
note: Ancient Greek athletes trained and competed in the nude

text: Arabic numerals (0-9) were developed in India, not in Arabia.
false: The numerals 0 through 9 were invented by Arab mathematicians.
note: Developed in India, transmitted to Europe via Arab scholars, hence the misnomer

text: Thomas Edison did not invent the light bulb; he improved upon designs by many earlier inventors.
false: Thomas Edison invented the first electric light bulb.
note: Humphry Davy, Warren de la Rue, and many others contributed earlier designs

text: Al Gore never claimed to have invented the internet.
false: Al Gore claimed he invented the internet.
note: He said he 'took the initiative in creating the Internet' referring to legislation

text: The QWERTY keyboard layout was not designed to slow down typists.
false: The QWERTY keyboard layout was specifically designed to slow down typists.
note: It was designed to reduce jamming in mechanical typewriters by separating common letter pairs

text: The first electronic general-purpose computer was ENIAC, completed in 1945.
false: The first computer was invented by Apple in the 1970s.
note: ENIAC was completed in 1945; Colossus (1943) was earlier but special-purpose

text: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web, not the internet itself.
false: Tim Berners-Lee invented the internet.
note: The internet (ARPANET) predates the Web by decades; Berners-Lee created HTTP and HTML in 1989

text: Apple's Macintosh was not the first personal computer with a graphical user interface; the Xerox Alto preceded it.
false: The Apple Macintosh was the first computer to use a graphical user interface.
note: Xerox Alto (1973) and Xerox Star (1981) had GUIs before the Mac (1984)

text: Moore's Law is an observation about transistor density, not a law of physics.
false: Moore's Law is a fundamental law of physics that guarantees computing power will double every two years.
note: An empirical observation by Gordon Moore in 1965; no physical law mandates it

text: The first text message (SMS) was sent in 1992, not in the 2000s.
false: The first text message was sent in 2001.
note: Neil Papworth sent 'Merry Christmas' on Dec 3, 1992

text: Bitcoin was created by the pseudonymous Satoshi Nakamoto in 2008, whose real identity remains unknown.
false: Bitcoin was created by a known computer scientist at Stanford University.
note: Satoshi Nakamoto published the Bitcoin whitepaper in 2008; identity remains unconfirmed

text: USB stands for Universal Serial Bus.
false: USB stands for Universal System Bridge.
note: Developed in the mid-1990s by a consortium including Intel, Microsoft, and others

text: Incognito or private browsing mode does not make you anonymous on the internet.
false: Using incognito mode makes your browsing completely anonymous and untraceable.
note: It only prevents local browser history; ISPs, websites, and network admins can still see activity

text: Wi-Fi does not stand for "wireless fidelity"; the name is a trademark with no underlying meaning.
false: Wi-Fi stands for Wireless Fidelity.
note: The Wi-Fi Alliance hired Interbrand to create a catchy name; it is not an acronym

text: Nikola Tesla, not Edison, championed alternating current (AC) power distribution.
false: Thomas Edison invented and championed alternating current electrical systems.
note: Edison promoted DC; Tesla and Westinghouse championed AC, which won the 'War of Currents'

text: The first website went live at CERN in 1991, created by Tim Berners-Lee.
false: The first website was created by Google in 1998.
note: info.cern.ch was the address of the first website, describing the World Wide Web project

text: The programming language Python is named after Monty Python, not the snake.
false: The programming language Python is named after the python snake.
note: Guido van Rossum named it after Monty Python's Flying Circus

text: Eating carrots does not significantly improve night vision beyond correcting a vitamin A deficiency.
false: Eating carrots gives you significantly better night vision.
note: British WWII propaganda to hide radar technology; only helps if vitamin A deficient

text: Spinach is not an exceptionally high source of iron compared to other leafy greens.
false: Spinach contains extraordinarily more iron than any other vegetable.
note: A misplaced decimal point in 1870s German research inflated the iron content by 10x

text: Breakfast is not necessarily the most important meal of the day for all people.
false: Skipping breakfast is always unhealthy and leads to weight gain.
note: The claim was popularized by cereal company marketing; research shows individual variation

text: Eating fat does not necessarily make you fat; excess calories from any source cause weight gain.
false: Eating dietary fat is the primary cause of body fat gain.
note: Total caloric surplus matters more than macronutrient source

text: MSG (monosodium glutamate) has not been shown to cause adverse reactions in controlled studies.
false: MSG has been scientifically proven to cause headaches and other adverse reactions.
note: Double-blind studies have failed to replicate 'Chinese Restaurant Syndrome'

text: Dark chocolate has some demonstrated cardiovascular benefits in moderate amounts.
false: All types of chocolate are equally unhealthy with no nutritional benefits.
note: Flavanols in dark chocolate have documented effects on blood pressure and blood flow

text: Drinking eight glasses of water per day is not a universal medical requirement.
false: Everyone must drink exactly eight glasses of water per day for good health.
note: Fluid needs vary by person, activity, and climate; food provides significant water intake

text: Detox diets and cleanses have no scientific basis; the liver and kidneys handle detoxification naturally.
false: Detox diets are necessary to remove toxins that the body cannot eliminate on its own.
note: No evidence that commercial detox products do anything the body doesn't already do

text: Organic foods have not been consistently shown to be more nutritious than conventionally grown foods.
false: Organic food is always significantly more nutritious than conventionally grown food.
note: Meta-analyses find minimal nutritional differences; organic may have lower pesticide residues

text: Celery does not have negative calories; it provides more energy than is used to digest it.
false: Celery has negative calories because chewing and digesting it burns more calories than it contains.
note: A stalk of celery has ~6 calories; digestion uses roughly 0.5 calories

text: Gluten is only harmful to people with celiac disease or diagnosed gluten sensitivity.
false: Gluten is unhealthy for everyone and should be avoided by all people.
note: About 1% of people have celiac disease; for most people, gluten is harmless

text: Coffee does not stunt children's growth; there is no scientific evidence for this claim.
false: Drinking coffee stunts the growth of children and adolescents.
note: No evidence links caffeine consumption to reduced height

text: Microwaving food does not destroy nutrients more than other cooking methods; it can actually preserve them better.
false: Microwaving food destroys all of its nutritional value.
note: Short cooking times and minimal water can preserve more nutrients than boiling

text: Brown eggs and white eggs have no nutritional difference; shell color is determined by the breed of hen.
false: Brown eggs are more nutritious than white eggs.
note: Shell color depends on hen breed; nutrition depends on diet and living conditions

text: Alcohol does not warm your body; it actually causes heat loss by dilating blood vessels near the skin.
false: Drinking alcohol warms your body and protects against hypothermia.
note: Vasodilation creates a sensation of warmth but accelerates core temperature loss

text: Learning styles (visual, auditory, kinesthetic) have no scientific support as a basis for teaching methods.
false: Students learn best when teaching matches their individual learning style.
note: Multiple meta-analyses find no evidence that matching instruction to learning styles improves outcomes

text: The Stanford Prison Experiment's conclusions are widely questioned due to methodological problems and coaching of participants.
false: The Stanford Prison Experiment conclusively proved that anyone can become abusive when given authority.
note: Demand characteristics, coaching by Zimbardo, and selective reporting undermine the conclusions

text: The "bystander effect" is more nuanced than typically presented; bystanders often do help in real emergencies.
false: The bystander effect proves that people will never help in an emergency when others are present.
note: Meta-analyses show the effect is weaker and less consistent than textbooks claim

text: There is no scientific evidence that subliminal advertising meaningfully influences consumer behavior.
false: Subliminal messages hidden in advertisements effectively control consumer purchasing decisions.
note: James Vicary's 1957 popcorn experiment was fabricated; replications show no meaningful effects

text: Polygraph (lie detector) tests are not reliable measures of deception.
false: Polygraph tests are highly accurate scientific instruments for detecting lies.
note: The National Academy of Sciences found polygraphs too unreliable for security screening

text: The Milgram obedience experiment's original results have been questioned due to variability across conditions and potential coaching.
false: The Milgram experiment proved that exactly 65% of all people will blindly follow authority to harm others.
note: Obedience varied from 0-100% across conditions; the 65% figure is from one specific setup

text: Multitasking generally reduces cognitive performance; the brain switches between tasks rather than doing them simultaneously.
false: The human brain can efficiently perform multiple complex cognitive tasks simultaneously.
note: Cognitive research consistently shows task-switching costs in speed and accuracy

text: Humans can form new neurons throughout adulthood through neurogenesis, particularly in the hippocampus.
false: Humans are born with all the neurons they will ever have and cannot generate new ones.
note: Adult neurogenesis was confirmed in the 1990s, primarily in the hippocampus

text: The "left brain/right brain" dominance theory is an oversimplification; both hemispheres contribute to most tasks.
false: People are either left-brained (logical) or right-brained (creative), and this determines their personality.
note: fMRI studies show both hemispheres are active during virtually all cognitive tasks

text: Repressed memories recovered in therapy are not considered scientifically reliable.
false: Memories repressed by trauma can be reliably recovered through therapeutic techniques.
note: Research shows recovered memories can be false memories created by suggestion

text: The Rorschach inkblot test has limited reliability and validity as a diagnostic psychological tool.
false: The Rorschach inkblot test is a highly accurate diagnostic tool for mental illness.
note: Inter-rater reliability is low; validity for most diagnoses is poorly supported

text: Grief does not follow a universal five-stage process; Kubler-Ross's model was based on dying patients, not bereaved people.
false: Everyone processes grief in the same five sequential stages: denial, anger, bargaining, depression, acceptance.
note: The model was about terminal patients' reactions; grief responses are highly individual

text: There is no credible scientific evidence for extrasensory perception (ESP).
false: Scientific experiments have proven that some people have extrasensory perception.
note: Decades of research have failed to produce replicable evidence of ESP

text: Memory does not work like a video recorder; memories are reconstructed each time they are recalled.
false: Human memory works like a video camera, recording events exactly as they happen.
note: Memories are reconstructive; each recall can alter the memory

text: The Mozart effect — that listening to Mozart makes you smarter — has not been replicated in subsequent studies.
false: Listening to Mozart's music has been scientifically proven to permanently increase intelligence.
note: The original 1993 study showed a temporary spatial reasoning improvement; not replicated reliably

text: The Sun is a main-sequence star classified as a G-type yellow dwarf, and it is roughly middle-aged at 4.6 billion years.
false: The Sun is a young star that formed about 500 million years ago.
note: The Sun is about 4.6 billion years old, roughly halfway through its main-sequence life

text: There is no permanent dark side of the Moon; all parts receive sunlight as the Moon rotates.
false: One side of the Moon is permanently dark and never receives sunlight.
note: The far side receives equal sunlight; it is the far side, not the dark side

text: The Sun is white when viewed from space, not yellow.
false: The Sun is actually yellow in color when viewed from space.
note: Earth's atmosphere scatters blue light, making the Sun appear yellow from the surface

text: A black hole is not a hole or a vacuum cleaner; it is an extremely dense concentration of mass.
false: A black hole is an empty hole in space that sucks in everything around it like a vacuum.
note: Objects must cross the event horizon to be trapped; black holes do not pull more than equivalent mass

text: The asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter is mostly empty space, not a dense field of rocks.
false: The asteroid belt is so densely packed with rocks that spacecraft cannot safely fly through it.
note: Average distance between asteroids is millions of kilometers; spacecraft pass through routinely

text: The North Star (Polaris) is not the brightest star in the night sky; Sirius holds that distinction.
false: The North Star (Polaris) is the brightest star visible in the night sky.
note: Polaris is about 48th in brightness; Sirius is the brightest

text: Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006 by the International Astronomical Union.
false: Pluto is still officially classified as the ninth planet in our solar system.
note: IAU Resolution B5 in 2006 established the dwarf planet category

text: Meteors (shooting stars) are typically tiny particles, often no larger than a grain of sand.
false: Shooting stars are caused by large boulders burning up in the atmosphere.
note: Most visible meteors are caused by particles 1mm to 1cm in size

text: The Great Wall of China is not visible from the Moon; no human-made structure is visible from that distance.
false: The Great Wall of China is visible from the Moon with the naked eye.
note: From the Moon, even continents are barely visible; confirmed by Apollo astronauts

text: The observable universe has a diameter of about 93 billion light-years, despite being only 13.8 billion years old.
false: The universe cannot be larger than 13.8 billion light-years across because it is 13.8 billion years old.
note: The expansion of space means light from the edge has traveled farther than 13.8 billion light-years

text: It is not illegal to remove a mattress tag if you are the consumer who purchased it.
false: It is illegal to remove the tag from a mattress under any circumstances.
note: The warning is directed at retailers and manufacturers, not consumers

text: Undercover police officers in the United States are not legally required to identify themselves when asked.
false: An undercover police officer must tell you they are a cop if you ask them directly.
note: No such legal requirement exists; this would defeat the purpose of undercover work

text: Miranda rights only need to be read when a suspect is both in custody and being interrogated.
false: Police must read you your Miranda rights the moment they arrest you.
note: Miranda applies to custodial interrogation; failure to read them doesn't invalidate the arrest

text: Finding money on the ground does not automatically make it yours under US law.
false: If you find money on the ground in the US, it is legally yours to keep with no obligations.
note: Most states have found property statutes requiring reasonable attempts to find the owner

text: A verbal contract can be legally binding in the United States.
false: A contract is only legally valid if it is in writing.
note: Oral contracts are enforceable, though some contracts must be written under the Statute of Frauds

text: Double jeopardy protects against being tried twice for the same offense by the same sovereign, but federal and state are separate sovereigns.
false: Double jeopardy means you can never be tried twice for the same crime under any circumstances in the US.
note: The separate sovereigns doctrine allows both federal and state prosecution for the same act

text: Citizens have the right to film police officers performing their duties in public spaces in the United States.
false: It is illegal to film or record police officers while they are on duty in the United States.
note: Multiple federal courts have affirmed this as a First Amendment right

text: There is no legal waiting period of 24 or 48 hours before you can file a missing person report in the US.
false: You must wait 24 hours before you can file a missing person report.
note: Police can accept missing person reports immediately; delays can be dangerous

text: Copyright protection in the US applies automatically when a work is created; registration is not required.
false: A creative work is not protected by copyright in the US until it is formally registered with the government.
note: Copyright attaches at creation; registration is needed only to sue for statutory damages

text: In the US, entrapment requires that law enforcement induced someone to commit a crime they were not predisposed to commit.
false: Any time a police officer provides an opportunity to commit a crime, it legally constitutes entrapment.
note: Simply providing an opportunity is not entrapment; the defense requires inducement by the government
